title-group.article-title: Exercise training and cardiac rehabilitation in patients with implantable cardioverter defibrillators: a review of current literature focusing on safety, effects of exercise training, and the psychological impact of programme participation

author-notes.corresp: Kjetil Isaksen, Department of Cardiology, Stavanger University Hospital, PO Box 8100, 4068 Stavanger, Norway Email: kjetil.isaksen@lyse.net

permissions.copyright-statement: © The European Society of Cardiology 2011 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: Background: Indications for implantable cardioverter defibrillators (ICDs) have been widened considerably during the last decade due to the well-documented effect in the heart failure population. Exercise training (ET) has a 1 A recommendation in heart failure. However, data on safety and efficacy of ET in patients with ICDs is sparse. ICD shocks are associated with reduced quality of life and increased mortality. Whether ET may have a beneficial effect in heart failure patients with an ICD is not well documented.
Methods: This review is based on a systematic search in the Pub Med database using the terms ‘exercise training’, ‘implantable cardioverter defibrillator’, and ‘cardiac rehabilitation’.

Results: Nine studies were identified, comprising 1889 patients. The average duration of exercise-based cardiac rehabilitation (CR) was 9.6 weeks. Ten ICD therapies (seven shocks) were reported in the 834 patients with ICD during ET. Between exercise sessions and during follow up 182 events were recorded including 166 shocks. Three studies (2 randomized) showed that the control group representing sedentary patients were more prone to ICD discharge than patients undergoing CR/ET. In all studies the ICD patients improved their aerobic fitness following ET. Few studies report data on the effect of ET on anxiety and depression.

Conclusion: Based on the current literature, ET in patients with an ICD seems to be safe and is not associated with increased risk of shocks. ET improves aerobic capacity in ICD patients, while effects on anxiety, depression and quality of life are still under debate.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Implantable cardioverter defibrillators (ICD) in patients resuscitated from sudden cardiac death is associated with a significant survival benefit.1–5 The extension of the indications for this device to patients with symptomatic heart failure and a left ventricular ejection fraction (EF) below 30% has led to an explosive increase in implantation rates in the Western world.6

The beneficial effects of cardiac rehabilitation (CR) and exercise training (ET) on physical and psychosocial functioning in heart failure patients are well established.7–11 However, heart failure patients with an ICD often seem reluctant to participate in CR due to the fear of an ET-induced shock.12,13 Anxiety and depression are more pronounced in the ICD population compared to the population at large, and avoidance of behaviour typically involving increased physical activity are frequently reported.14 On the other hand sparse data exist on whether ET might reduce anxiety and depression.

Neither the European Society of Cardiology (ESC) nor the American Heart Association/American College of Cardiology (AHA/ACC) has prepared separate guidelines on CR/ET for the specified ICD patient. As a consequence of this, physician recommendations to ICD patients regarding participation in ET vary widely.15 However, a consensus document from the Study Group of Sports Cardiology of the Working Group of Cardiac Rehabilitation and Exercise Physiology, and the Working Group of Myocardial and Pericardial Diseases of the European Society of Cardiology suggests sports activity in stable patients at a low static or dynamic intensity.16 Moreover, the study group on Sports cardiology of the European Association for Cardiovascular Prevention and Rehabilitation suggests that the indication for an ICD is no substitute for the guidelines relating to the underlying pathology.17

The aims of this review on exercise training in ICD patients are to assess the following:
Risk of arrhythmia during exercise: safety and feasibility of ET in ICD patients
Aerobic fitness response to ET in the ICD patient population
Impact of ET on psychosocial wellbeing/health

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: We conducted a systematic literature search using Pub Med by combining the key words ‘exercise training’ and ‘implantable cardioverter defibrillator’ with ‘cardiac rehabilitation’. Publications thought to contain relevant information on the topic were extracted. Both retrospective and prospective studies were included. We also examined the reference list from relevant articles found on Pub Med.

sec.title: Results
sec.p:
Nine studies published between 2001 and 2009 were identified to contain relevant information on the topic. Descriptive data on the studies are depicted in Table 1.18–26 From this pool of studies seven had a prospective design, while two were retrospective. Table 1.

The number of patients in each study ranged from ten to 938. In total 1889 patients were included, while 834 ICD patients have participated in ET in the various trials. Three studies are prospective, randomized and controlled with ICD patients in both exercise and sedentary arms. The duration of organized cardiac rehabilitation varied between 4 and 12 weeks. Four studies report data only from the cardiac rehabilitation period,19,21,22,24 while the remaining five also report data from follow-up periods ranging from 12 weeks to 48 months.18,20,23,25,26 As shown in Table 1, ischaemic heart disease was the underlying condition in the majority of patients. The degree of left ventricular function in the various studies varied between an EF of 25–44%, the former referring to the HF-ACTION trial. A major limitation of the literature data is that they are mostly referring to secondary prevention patients, whereas the increase in ICD implantations is based on primary prophylaxis.
Due to the heterogeneity of the studies the patient populations cannot be pooled in order to perform a meta-analysis.

sec.title: Risk of arrhythmia during exercise: safety and feasibility of exercise training in ICD patients
sec.p: During exercise, ten ICD therapies have been described in the population of 834 ICD patients (Table 1). Seven of the ten events were shocks, two of which were inappropriate. Six of the ten ICD therapies occurred in the same study,21 leaving four events (three appropriate and one inappropriate) in the remaining eight studies comprising 742 ICD patients.
Between exercise sessions, 182 events were recorded.

For the studies with sedentary ICD controls (Table 1), ICD discharges were more frequent in the sedentary control group than in the ET group. The multicentre randomized controlled HF-ACTION trial examining the effects of exercise training in 2331 heart failure patients contained 938 patients with an ICD. Regarding safety, one exercise session was terminated due to an ICD discharge in this large study. Further, the total number of ICD discharges throughout the study was somewhat lower in the exercise group compared with the sedentary control group. In the randomized study by Belardinelli et al.20 the sedentary ICD control group comprising 22 patients had eight ICD shocks leading to hospitalizations compared to none in the 30 ET patients during the study period and 18-month follow up.

sec.title: Aerobic fitness response to exercise training in the ICD patient population
sec.p: All studies used different types of aerobic exercise, including ergometer cycling and walking or running on a treadmill. Intensity levels ranged from 60 to 80% of maximal heart rate or heart rate reserve. The evaluation of the ET effect on cardiovascular capacity/fitness varied between the different studies.

Pre- and post-interventional maximal oxygen uptake (VO2max) testing was performed in five of nine studies. The two studies by Vanhees et al.19,21 comprising 100 ICD patients and 489 non-ICD cardiac controls compared the effectiveness of ET in ICD versus non-ICD patients. Both ICD and control groups achieved significant improvements in VO2max with a more pronounced effect in the non-ICD group. It is important to note that in the HF-ACTION trial ET lead to a 4% increase in peak oxygen consumption and hence failed to reach the 10% targeted improvement specified in the study protocol. In numbers, VO2max increased from baseline 14.4 to 15 ml/kg/min after 3 months in the intervention group. Belardinelli et al.20 documented a significant improvement in VO2max following ET in ICD patients compared with no changes in ICD control patients. The remaining prospective studies used the change in ergometric load and the treadmill test time during the ET programme as measures for improvements in aerobic fitness, all reporting significant improvements.

sec.title: Impact of exercise training on psychosocial wellbeing/health
sec.p:
Three studies including 78 ICD patients reported data on psychosocial functioning after ET (Table 2). In the study by Fitchet et al.18 patients were supervised by a health psychologist in addition to the ET programme. Although this study included only 16 patients, significant reductions in depression and anxiety immediately after and at follow up 12 weeks post ET were reported. Belardinelli et al.20 also referred to significant improvements in psychological wellbeing. These improvements were seen in the subsegment of cardiac resynchronization therapy patients, evaluated with the Minnesota Living with Heart Failure questionnaire. No significant improvement of psychological wellbeing was found in the ICD group. Table 2.
Psychological effects of exercise training/cardiac rehabilitation on implantable cardioverter defibrillator patients in cardiac rehabilitation programme

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The studies included in this review reported seven shocks during exercise training in 834 ICD patients. The shocks were recorded over an average training period of 9.6 weeks. Patients participating in exercise training in two randomized controlled studies had a reduced frequency of shocks between the ET sessions compared with sedentary controls. Although ET is well established in the rehabilitation of patients with heart disease including patients with heart failure, only sparse data exist with regard to the safety and exercise effects in patients with an ICD. Most studies reported are not randomized and have a heterogeneous design. However, all nine studies included in this review consistently indicate that ET is beneficial also in ICD patients. Further, patients who have received an ICD based on the MADIT II criteria, have a 1A indication for ET. Hence, we should assure that these patients can profit from the benefits of ET.

Unfortunately, the randomized multicentre RELAX-ICD trial was recently terminated due to recruitment problems. This trial with three arms was designed to compare the effects of ET to exercise in combination with cognitive behavioural therapy (CBT) with a third arm serving as a control group without intervention. Recruitment of the ICD patients to exercise training was not the problematic issue; however, execution of the CBT part of the study was difficult. This highlights an important and problematic issue, namely the vast resources needed over multiple specialties (cardiologists, physiotherapists, psychologists) to carry out such complex trials.

sec.title: Risk of arrhythmia during exercise: safety and feasibility of exercise training in ICD patients
sec.p: All patients with an ICD should be evaluated with an exercise stress test before entering an ET programme to assess potential inducible ischaemia and arrhythmia. Further, the maximal achievable heart rate in response to an incremental stress test should be considerably below the programmed ICD threshold for therapy to minimize the risk for inappropriate shocks.

The incidence of cardiovascular events during organized ET programmes in the population with coronary heart disease is very low with one estimated major cardiovascular complication per 100,000 patient hours and one fatality per 750,000 patient-hours.27 The ICD population however constitutes a subset of patients with an increased risk for arrhythmic complications. Following an initial evaluation including a stress test, ICD patients may enrol in an ET programme under the supervision of experienced staff with necessary skills in cardiopulmonary resuscitation. Following these steps most ICD patients will do fine without any specific surveillance in the ET setting, leaving special attention for high-risk ICD patients.

We should aim towards giving ICD patients the opportunity to conduct an active lifestyle spanning from the daily physical activities of life to ET. Thus, they should be encouraged to continue organized and unorganized activity after a run-in period in a rehabilitation centre. Based on the findings from the few ICD training studies and on the data from the heart failure training trials, this might even decrease costs related to the continuing rehabilitation of this patient population. The HF-ACTION study26 has already proved the safety and benefit of ET in the heart failure population. In this study 45% of the 2331 patients included had an ICD. Only one patient had an ICD discharge during exercise in the intervention group leading to a premature end of the training session.

In the current reports no fatalities occurred during ET and no pre-exercise programme tests were terminated due to pulse rates close to ICD threshold, probably due to the heart rate lowering effect of beta-blockers in this population.

sec.title: Aerobic fitness response to exercise training in the ICD patient population
sec.p: All cited studies reported an exercise induced increase in aerobic capacity in the ICD group. However, Vanhees et al.21 found smaller but significant improvements in VO2max in the ICD population compared with non-ICD cardiac controls following CR. It is also worth noting that Belardinelli et al.20 found greater improvements in aerobic fitness in the cardiac resynchronization therapy group compared with ICD only.

As the effect of ET on aerobic capacity in heart failure is dependent on exercise intensity, this difference could be a consequence of ICD patients being afraid of training at high intensity levels. The use of beta-blockers does not prevent the effect of ET on VO2max in patients with heart failure, as shown by Wisløff et al.28

sec.title: Mechanisms
sec.p: In patients with ischaemic heart disease (IHD), prolonged and repeated training sessions inducing myocardial ischaemia lasting up to 60 min are well tolerated without evidence of myocardial injury, significant arrhythmias or left ventricular dysfunction.29 On the other hand, there are also reports that ET in the ischaemic heart may elicit potentially fatal arrhythmias, as observed during stress ECG testing prior to revascularization.30,31

Although most patients are revascularized before entering an ET programme, ischaemia may be apparent in parts of the myocardium during training at high intensity in patients with coronary artery disease. A successive increase in intensity during the programme may thus induce beneficial effects like collateral formation and improved endothelial function, which reduce ischaemia during bouts of exercise.

sec.title: Impact of exercise training on psychosocial aspects like anxiety and depression
sec.p: Anxiety and fear are the dominant psychological manifestations experienced by ICD recipients.32 In addition depressive symptoms in this population are common and associated with increased mortality.33 The strongest predictor for this psychopathological response has been shown to be the frequency of shocks experienced.34–36 However, the underlying mechanisms are complex and multifactorial.37 The type D personality, characterized by high negative effect and high social inhibition, has been linked to the development of chronic anxiety in this population.38 Female gender and younger age also seem to predispose for anxiety and ICD concerns.39 Factors like the perception of control of shocks, as well as the predictability of shocks and psychological attributions made by the patient regarding the device also has to be considered.

Several studies have described ICD recipients’ fear of shock due to overexertion (high pulse rates), which subsequently may lead to a persistently reduced physical activity levels.40,41 This fear of exercise is also negatively associated with health-related quality of life.13 In the current review we found a positive effect both on quality of life measured with the Minnesota Living with Heart Failure questionnaire and reduced symptoms of depression and anxiety (Table 2). However, only three studies with a total of 78 ICD patients constitute a weak foundation. As depicted in Table 2, no uniform conclusions can be made on the existing knowledge base regarding these issues.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: In this review we found that ET in ICD patients seems to be safe. Due to lack of significant scientific evidence it is not possible to conclude on whether ET may be associated with a reduced risk for arrhythmias and/or ICD shocks. However, ET improves functional capacity and may also improve quality of life.

Several programmes are now running to study the ET effects in patients with an ICD. We are currently performing a controlled trial to evaluate mechanisms and psychological aspects in ICD patients related to training (ClinicalTrials.gov identifier NCT01038960). However, large randomized controlled trials are needed to document the beneficial effects of ET in the increasing population of ICD patients, not only with regard to morbidity, but also with regard to anxiety, depression and quality of life.

Guidelines for ET in patients with an ICD are no substitute for the guidelines relating to the underlying pathology. Based on the existing data we have constructed a simplified flow scheme for the pre- exercise evaluation and execution of ET in patients with ischaemic cardiomyopaty and an ICD (Figure 1). Figure 1.
Flow scheme for assessment of patients with ischaemic cardiomyopathy and ICD with regard to exercise training.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.

sec.title: Conflicts of interest
sec.p: None.
